966385768510971905.text: This also solves the sibyl problem and vote stuffing/brigading very effectively - you’re counting *arguments*, not *participants*.

966385140439093248.text: Referring back to https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7282.txt , one of the key insights is that consensus is reached not based on a majority, or a lack of objectors, but when all objections have either been addressed or found without merit (the full description is too long for a tweet - go read it!)

963626278032048128.text:
This is a hugely important step for the Ethereum community.  This technology is bigger than any company or legal entity.

It is for all of humanity, just like the Internet and Web before it.

I heartily approve of this proposal

962236989360701440.text: Better question: How do we create the processes and norms which ensure that the EIP process is secure against adversaries, represents the interests of stakeholders, and maintains its legitimacy over time? https://twitter.com/pirapira/status/962234809421623297 …

963469052516622336.text: Applying the word "governance" to the residual human decision-making needed for public blockchains carries, as the term is thought of by non-developers, tons of baggage that is irrelevant to the only necessary category of such decisions, namely decisions about upgrading software.

963353576926887936.text: 12/ TL;DR: Blockchain governance should be a question of expertise, not democracy.

1112182282612203520.text: [The Core Developers] work for the best interest of the protocol. Not just from a technical perspective, but also from a long term survival perspective. - Andrew - ethereum/governance - Mar 29
